questions.text: A newborn presents with profuse bilious vomiting at birth with fullness in the epigastric region. X- Ray shows the 'double bubble' sign. Which of the following pathologies is this associated with?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Duodenal atresia The ‘double bubble’ sign indicates gas in the stomach and proximal duodenum. If not treated it becomes fatal as a result of fluid shifts and electrolyte imbalances. Fullness in the epigastric region is a result of the stomach being full of gas. In esophageal atresia, the baby typically presents with choking rather than vomiting.

Highyeild:

Duodenal atresia is a congenital anomaly that results from the failure of vacuolization of the duodenum during its solid cord stage. There are three anatomic variants of duodenal atresia, which are Type I (mucosal web with the intact muscular wall), Type II (two ends separated by a fibrous cord), and Type III (complete separation with a gap within the duodenum) .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Patient with esophageal atresia presents early in life with drooling of saliva and unable to take oral feeds, recoiling of NGT Option: B. In congenital intestinal obstruction a plain film will show more pathognomonic features of obstruction. Option: C. In gastric outlet obstruction there is no bile in the vomit and, most importantly, it presents later at about 4 weeks whereas duodenal atresia presents at birth.

Extraedge:

Duodenal atresia is associated with various anomalies such as prematurity, Down syndrome, polyhydramnios, malrotation, annular pancreas, biliary atresia, cardiac, renal, esophageal, and anorectal anomalies.

questions.text: Within a few hours of being born, a baby presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. Which one of the following is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Meconium ileus Meconium ileus can cause neonatal intestinal obstruction and typically presents in patients with cystic fibrosis in 10 percent of cases, where the deficiency of pancreatic enzymes causes the meconium to be thick and viscous. It presents within the first few hours of life with absolute constipation, bile-stained vomiting, and abdominal distension. Meconium is normally passed within the first 24 hours but this fails to occur. Abdominal X-ray (AXR) may display a mottled appearance from the lipid droplets within the meconium . It may be difficult to differentiate from Hirschsprung disease but this typically has multiple air-fluid levels on erect Abdominal X-Ray

Highyeild:

Meconium ileus is a condition that affects approximately 15% of patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). It is the earliest clinical manifestation of CF. Simple meconium ileus is characterized by the terminal ileum being dilated and filled with thick, tarlike, inspissated meconium, with smaller pellets of meconium found in the more distal ileum leading into a relatively small colon. Patients present with signs and symptoms of distal intestinal obstruction . Diagnosis is typically made using an abdominal X-ray or a water-soluble (Gastrografin) contrast a enema. Treatment options include a water-soluble contrast enema , which is successful in relieving the obstruction in up to 75% of cases with a low bowel perforation rate.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Hirschsprung’s disease is a congenital disease where the affected individuals lack mural ganglionic cells in the colon leading to constipation and abdominal distension. Rectal biopsy is the diagnostic investigation of choice to demonstrate the deficiency. Option: B. Gastric outlet obstruction usually presents with non-bilious vomiting. Option: C. Duodenal atresia - bilious vomiting since birth, mother has a history of polyhydramnios.

Extraedge:

Operative management is required when the obstruction cannot be relieved with contrast enema. Simple evacuation of the luminal meconium without the need to create a stoma is all that is necessary in most cases. Proximal and distal bowel irrigation with either warmed saline solution or 4% N-acetylcysteine can be helpful. The Bishop-Koop operation with an irrigation stoma is rarely used in meconium ileus.

questions.text: A 2-day-old baby has not passed Meconium. Examination reveals a diffusely tender abdomen with absent bowel sounds. A plain abdominal X-ray (AXR) shows a distended colon. A rectal biopsy is performed and demonstrates a lack of mural ganglionic cells. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hirschsprung’s disease Hirschsprung’s disease is a congenital disease where the affected individuals lack mural ganglionic cells in the colon leading to constipation and abdominal distension. Rectal biopsy is the diagnostic investigation of choice to demonstrate the deficiency. Meconium ileus can cause neonatal intestinal obstruction and typically presents in patients with cystic fibrosis in 10 percent of cases, where the deficiency of pancreatic enzymes causes the meconium to be thick and viscous. It presents within the first few hours of life with absolute constipation, bile-stained vomiting, and abdominal distension.

Highyeild:

Hirschsprung’s disease Hirschsprung’s disease is a rare congenital disorder that affects about 1 in 5000 live births. The rectosigmoid colon is the most commonly affected site (75% of cases) , followed by the splenic flexure or transverse colon (17%) , and the entire colon with variable extension into the small bowel (8%) . Individuals with a positive family history of Down's syndrome have an increased risk of the disease. Hirschsprung’s disease is a type of neurocristopathy that results from the defective migration of neural crest cells to the colonic mucosa. The disease is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric ( Auerbach’s ) and submucosal ( Meissner’s ) plexus, with hypertrophy of nerve trunks in the plexus. This leads to a muscular spasm of the distal colon and internal anal sphincter, resulting in functional obstruction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Duodenal atresia - bilious vomiting since birth, mother has a history of polyhydramnios Option: B. Pyloric stenosis - common in 1st born male child, patient is normal at birth, but symptoms start after 2-3 weeks. Option: D. Meconium is normally passed within the first 24 hours but this fails to occur. Abdominal X-ray (AXR) may display a mottled appearance from the lipid droplets within the meconium. It may be difficult to differentiate from Hirschsprung disease, but the absence of ganglion cells confirms the diagnosis.

Extraedge:

A digital examination can reveal that the rectum is empty, and rapid expulsion of feces often follows the examination. Repeated tube decompression and gentle rectal washouts with normal saline can have a positive and significant clinical impact on these patients. Treatment depends on the extent of the disease, with extended myectomy for short-segment disease and a temporary colostomy followed by definitive procedures for long-segment disease. The prognosis for Hirschsprung’s disease is generally excellent, with constipation, soiling, incontinence, and enterocolitis being the most common postoperative problems

questions.text: A 15-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for grossly bloody diarrhea for 2 days. The girl has had a few episodes of blood-tinged stools over the past 3 weeks. She has not had pain, nausea, or vomiting. She is at the 55th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a small amount of dark red blood in the diaper. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.5 g/dL, her mean corpuscular volume is 68 ?m3, and her platelet count is 300,000/mm3. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Double bubble sign on abdominal x-ray.

options.label: D
options.text: Ectopic Gastric mucosa on technetium 99 pertechnetate scan

questions.correct_answer: D. Ectopic Gastric mucosa on technetium 99 pertechnetate scan
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ectopic Gastric mucosa on technetium 99 pertechnetate scan Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan showing ectopic gastric mucosa in the small bowel is diagnostic of Meckel diverticulum in children. Meckel diverticulum is a true diverticulum that may contain ectopic gastric mucosa and/or pancreatic tissue. Acid secretion by gastric mucosa within the diverticulum results in ileal ulceration and subsequent bleeding. Consequently, chronic blood loss can lead to iron deficiency anemia, and thus a low MCV, as seen in this patient.

Highyeild:

Meckel's Diverticulum Meckel's Diverticulum is the most commonly encountered congenital anomaly of the small intestine and occurs in 2% of the population. The "Rule of Two" in Meckel's Diverticulum refers to its 2% prevalence, 2-inch length, location 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve, and the fact that half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age. Meckel's Diverticulum is a true diverticulum as it has all three layers of the intestine and is located on the antimesenteric border of the ileum 45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve. Meckel's Diverticulum results from incomplete closure of the omphalomesenteric or vitellointestinal duct and is characterized by the presence of heterotopic tissue, with gastric mucosa being the most common (50%), followed by pancreatic mucosa (5%) and colonic mucosa (rarely). The most common clinical presentation of Meckel's Diverticulum is gastrointestinal bleeding (25-50% ), which is manifested as painless bright red blood from the rectum , with intermittent episodes persisting without treatment. Meckel's Diverticulum can also cause intestinal obstruction (31%), diverticulitis (10-20%), perforation, and peritonitis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Plain abdominal x-ray showing a double bubble sign is suggestive of duodenal atresia. This girl does not present with bilious vomiting or abdominal distention, which would be expected in this condition. Additionally, she is 15 months old and therefore past the window in which duodenal atresia would manifest (24–48 hours after birth). Option: B. Cobblestone mucosa (due to linear ulcerations of the mucosa) is a classical colonoscopic finding of Crohn’s disease (CD). Although intestinal blood loss in CD can cause iron deficiency anemia and a low MCV, as seen in this patient, this condition is associated with further symptoms such as nonbloody chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and failure to thrive. Moreover, since the peak incidence of CD is 15–35 years, it is unlikely in this 15-month-old patient. Option: C. In young children, abdominal ultrasound showing a target sign is suggestive of intussusception. While intussusception can cause lower gastrointestinal bleeding, it usually presents with acute cyclical colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal tenderness. This patient has a benign abdominal exam and no concomitant symptoms, making intussusception unlikely.

Extraedge:

Scintigraphy with sodium 99mTc-pertechnetate is the most accurate diagnostic test in children, while barium studies should be performed in adults with normal nuclear medicine findings. Treatment of symptomatic Meckel's Diverticulum involves diverticulectomy or resection of the segment of ileum bearing the diverticulum, while asymptomatic diverticula found in children during laparotomy should be resected .

questions.text: An 18-day-old newborn has difficulty feeding and diarrhea for 2 days. During this period he vomited after each of his feeds. He was born at 28 weeks gestation and weighed 1100 g. His feeds consist of breast milk and cow milk based-formula. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 67/min and blood pressure is 70/35 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness; rigidity and guarding are present. Bowel sounds are absent. The test of the stool for occult blood is positive. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 18,000/mm3 and platelet count is 78,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Necrotizing enterocolitis Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is the most common cause of an acute abdomen in premature infants with low birth weight. It typically occurs 2–4 weeks after birth, once oral feeding has begun. Infants present with poor feeding, lethargy, vomiting, diarrhea, hematochezia, thrombocytopenia, and/or a distended abdomen with decreased bowel sounds, all of which are present in this infant. The x-ray of the abdomen shows pneumatosis intestinalis, which confirms the diagnosis of NEC. Other typical X-ray findings include dilated bowel loops, portal venous gas, and abdominal free air (if bowel perforation occurs). The presence of abdominal tenderness, rigidity, guarding, and leukocytosis in this patient suggest peritonitis and necrotic bowel, which requires emergent laparotomy and likely resection of the affected bowel to prevent the progression of bowel necrosis, DIC, and shock.

Highyeild:

Necrotizing enterocolitis NEC is a condition that affects around 10% of premature infants in NICUs who have been fed for a few days or more. Breastfed infants are less likely to develop NEC than those fed with formula. NEC usually involves the colon and terminal ileum, and less commonly the jejunum and duodenum. Symptoms of mild NEC include feed intolerance, bilious aspirates, distension, and rectal bleeding. Treatment for mild NEC may include gut rest, antibiotics, and parenteral nutrition. Surgical intervention may be necessary if there is tenderness and signs of sepsis, or if the infant's condition worsens. Observation may be appropriate for a short time in some cases. The most seriously ill infants may have a mortality rate of around 30%. Radiological signs of NEC may include pneumatosis intestinalis, gas in the portal vein, and, if perforated, a pneumoperitoneum. Definitive surgery may involve bowel resection and anastomosis or a defunctioning stoma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Hirschsprung disease can present with abdominal distention, bilious emesis, and an inability to pass stool secondary to obstruction from an aganglionic portion of the rectosigmoid colon. Failure to pass meconium for > 48 hours and a positive squirt sign further supports this diagnosis. If the disease is complicated by enterocolitis, explosive bloody diarrhea is common. This patient developed symptoms > 2 weeks after delivery, which makes another diagnosis more likely. Moreover, an abdominal x-ray of Hirschsprung disease would show an absence of gas in the distal colon with a dilated bowel proximally rather than the pneumatosis intestinalis is seen here. Option: B. Meckel diverticulum is the most likely cause of painless hematochezia in children < 2 years old. Patients are often asymptomatic but may present with abdominal pain and hematochezia in case of infection, secondary volvulus, or bowel obstruction due to secondary intussusception. Meckel diverticulum cannot be visualized on a plain abdominal x-ray but requires a technetium-99m pertechnetate scan and is not associated with pneumatosis intestinalis. Therefore, another diagnosis is more likely in this child. Option: C . Duodenal atresia presents with abdominal distention, bilious emesis, and a prenatal history of polyhydramnios (since the fetus cannot drink the amniotic fluid due to the intestinal obstruction) but does not cause bloody diarrhea or peritonitis (i.e., abdominal rigidity and guarding). An abdominal x-ray would also show a double bubble sign rather than pneumatosis intestinalis. In addition, duodenal atresia is typically associated with chromosomal abnormalities, especially Down syndrome. This patient lacks any dysmorphic features to suggest a chromosomal abnormality.

Extraedge:

In severe cases, the dead intestine may need to be removed, with open bowel ends closed (clip and drop) , and the abdomen left open (laparostomy) with a vacuum dressing applied on low suction. Infants who survive NEC with over 40 cm of small intestine usually adapt within a few months, while others may require prolonged hospital stays or home parenteral nutrition.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with acute intermittent umbilical abdominal pain that began that morning. The pain radiates to his right lower abdomen and occurs every 15-30 minutes. During these episodes of pain, the boy draws up his knees to the chest. The patient has had several episodes of nonbilious vomiting. He had a similar episode 3 months ago. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.86°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows periumbilical tenderness with no masses palpated. His Hb is 10.6 g/dL.Abdominal ultrasound shows concentric rings of bowel in the transverse section. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Meckels diverticulum The boy's clinical features and Target sign on USG is suggestive of intussusception . Meckel diverticulum is the most common pathologic lead point causing intussusception. A pathological lead point should always be suspected in children older than 5 years of age who present with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, especially if symptoms occur within 6 months of the last episode. Meckel diverticulum can cause bleeding if it contains ectopic gastric mucosal cells that secrete gastric acid and can so irritate the adjacent small bowel to the point of ulceration, which explains this child's anemia.

Highyeild:

Meckel's Diverticulum Meckel's Diverticulum is the most commonly encountered congenital anomaly of the small intestine and occurs in 2% of the population. The "Rule of Two" in Meckel's Diverticulum refers to its 2% prevalence, 2-inch length, location 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve, and the fact that half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age. Meckel's Diverticulum is a true diverticulum as it has all three layers of the intestine and is located on the antimesenteric border of the ileum 45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve. Meckel's Diverticulum results from incomplete closure of the omphalomesenteric or vitellointestinal duct and is characterized by the presence of heterotopic tissue, with gastric mucosa being the most common (50%), followed by pancreatic mucosa (5%) and colonic mucosa (rarely). The most common clinical presentation of Meckel's Diverticulum is gastrointestinal bleeding (25-50% ), which is manifested as painless bright red blood from the rectum , with intermittent episodes persisting without treatment. Meckel's Diverticulum can also cause intestinal obstruction (31%), diverticulitis (10-20%), perforation, and peritonitis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Intestinal adhesions may cause bowel obstruction or act as a pathologic lead point for intussusception. They usually form after abdominal surgery, intra-abdominal inflammation, or abdominal radiotherapy, none of which are mentioned in this patient's history. Option: C. Acute appendicitis presents with diffuse, continuous abdominal pain migrating from the periumbilical region to the right lower quadrant, vomiting, and target sign on ultrasound, making it an important differential diagnosis for this patient's symptoms. However, repeated attacks of pain and the presence of anemia in this patient suggest a different diagnosis. Option: D. Malrotation with volvulus typically presents with acute onset of abdominal pain and bloody stools. On abdominal ultrasound, the classic feature of volvulus is the whirlpool sign (whirl sign), which indicates a twisted mesentery and is easily distinguished from the target sign seen in this patient. Although the clinical features may be similar to those of this patient's condition, volvulus caused by malrotation of the intestines usually occurs during early infancy and would be uncommon in a 6-year-old child.

Extraedge:

Scintigraphy with sodium 99mTc-pertechnetate is the most accurate diagnostic test in children, while barium studies should be performed in adults with normal nuclear medicine findings. Treatment of symptomatic Meckel's Diverticulum involves diverticulectomy or resection of the segment of ileum bearing the diverticulum, while asymptomatic diverticula found in children during laparotomy should be resected .

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy presents with vomiting and rectal bleeding. There is a sausage-shaped mass palpable on the left side of the abdomen. An image of abdominal ultrasound is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intussusception This is the classic story of intussusception, which occurs in young children and is most often idiopathic. There is redcurrant jelly stool due to bleeding. Intussusception is an invagination of one segment of the bowel into another segment of the bowel. Early symptoms are nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Later, rectal bleeding (‘redcurrant stool’) and a sausage-shaped mass may be palpable in the abdominal examination. An abdominal USG shows a doughnut sign.

Highyeild:

Hirschprung's disease - the absence of ganglionic cells in the colon. The newborn ll not pass meconium. Diagnosis is by biopsy.
